Felipe Rocha Pinto
November/2021 Advisors : Amaro Gomes Barreto Junior Carla Luciane Manske Camargo
Department : Engenharia de Processos QuÃ­micos e BioquÃ­micos

The thermodynamic description of the adsorption phenomenon can be made from the most varied assumptions and hypotheses, giving rise to models with different levels of thoroughness. Such models a re made of parameters, which require an estimation from experimental data. However, the experimental fluctuation associated with the data can lead to high uncertainties to parameters and consequently to the models. In this sense, two types of thermodynamic models were evaluated in the present work: explicit algebraic isotherm models (Langmuir and TÃ³th) and an equation of state model for confined fluids. Statistical inferences were made in terms of the constructi on of the optimization problem, verif ication o f adequacy of the models and verif ication of the parametersâ€™ probabilit y distribution. Statistical analysi s were performed under frequentist and Bayesian perspectives for a case of CO 2 adsorption on 13x Zeolite at different temperatures. Under the classica l statistical view, the estimation of para meters was performed employing Maximum L ikelihood estimation (MLE) using Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) and the Gauss -Newton method. Statistical analysis of parameters were performed by confidence regions in ter ms of elliptical approximation and likelihood region, while the evaluation of models was performed by Chi -square statistics. The results showed the importance of precisely knowing the experimental er rors. Under the Bayesian optics, MCMC (Markov -chain Monte Carlo) methods were applied to the models of interest. The study showed that MCMC technique provided the same information of the confidence regions of the parameters obtained by the Fisherian statistics, apart from allowing the propagation of parametric u ncertainties in the model's responses and the reconstruction of the parameters' probability density functions.
